general: This law allows the government to spend money from the Consolidated Fund to pay for things like salaries, buildings, and other expenses for the years 2009-2010. It also says how much money can be spent each year. This helps the government manage its finances and make sure there is enough money to pay for everything it needs to do.

series.short: "UK Government's Fiscal Year Budget and Borrowing Authorization (2008-2010)"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is authorized to spend up to £7,425,726,000 from the Consolidated Fund for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2009.
* Simplified point 2: The UK government is also authorized to borrow up to £32,112,484,000 from the Consolidated Fund for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2009.
* Simplified point 3: For the fiscal year ending March 31, 2010, the UK government is authorized to spend up to £202,426,196,000 from the Consolidated Fund.
* Simplified point 4: The UK government may also borrow up to £194,439,006,000 from the Consolidated Fund for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2010.
* Simplified point 5: This act can be referred to as the Consolidated Fund Act 2008.

summary: The Consolidated Fund Act 2008 allows the UK government to spend money from the Consolidated Fund for two financial years, 2008-2009 and 2009-2010. In 2008-2009, the government can spend up to £7,425,726,000 and borrow up to £32,112,484,000. In 2009-2010, the government can spend up to £202,426,196,000 and borrow up to £194,439,006,000. This law gives the government permission to use these funds for various purposes such as paying bills, funding public services, and investing in infrastructure projects.
single:
* Authorizes the use of £7,425,726,000 for the service of the year ending with 31 March 2009.
* Authorizes the use of £202,426,196,000 for the service of the year ending with 31 March 2010.
* Allows the Treasury to issue £32,112,484,000 out of the Consolidated Fund for the year ending with 31 March 2009.
* Allows the Treasury to issue £194,439,006,000 out of the Consolidated Fund for the year ending with 31 March 2010.
* Short title: Consolidated Fund Act 2008.
In simpler terms, this bill authorizes the government to spend certain amounts of money from the Consolidated Fund for the years 2008-2009 and 2009-2010. The bill allows the Treasury to issue money out of the Consolidated Fund for these years, and sets the amounts that can be spent. This bill is a legal requirement for the government to be able to spend money from the Consolidated Fund for these years.
